content.webTitle: AFL writer Caroline Wilson rejects Eddie McGuire's 'banter' excuse

fields.headline: AFL writer Caroline Wilson rejects Eddie McGuire's 'banter' excuse
fields.bodyText: Caroline Wilson has rejected the notion that Eddie McGuire’s comments about her were mere “banter” made in the spirit of a fundraising event and misconstrued during a sensitive week in the AFL that was meant to raise awareness of domestic violence. McGuire said on his radio show on Monday morning that his comments were in keeping with the tone of the general “tomfoolery” of last Monday’s charity event, the Big Freeze at the G. But Wilson, the Age’s chief AFL football writer, spoke to 3AW Breakfast on Monday morning and said McGuire had crossed a line when joking he would pay money to see her slide into an ice bath – and even more if she were to “stay under”. “I wasn’t happy about them [the comments],” Wilson said. “I found out about them last Monday night, they were relayed to me by a friend at Channel 9. “I think he’s probably crossed the line and I didn’t like the language. I don’t accept that it was playful banter, I’ve got to say. “It’s like casual racism, casual violent language might be meant as a joke, but I wonder how many times we have to draw this line in the sand between this sort of language and what is a joke and obviously what is completely unacceptable.” McGuire was contacted about the incident by the AFL’s chief executive, Gillon McLachlan, on Sunday although he denied reports he was told to apologise or resign from his post with the Magpies. He said his comments, which came before the AFL’s White Ribbon weekend, were made in the spirit on the charity event and merely taken the wrong way. “Anything, anything at all that can be seen to promulgate domestic violence is unacceptable. Full stop,” he said. “That’s the big issue here. You can argue as much as you like about the tone … but anything that is seen to promulgate or support – even in a light-hearted manner – any form of domestic violence is unacceptable. “That was the least of anyone’s intention. In fact, it didn’t even cross anyone’s mind. The day – the Big Freeze at the G – was based on good humour, sledging each other, tomfoolery. “The whole thing was about having fun at Gil’s expense, my expense, everyone’s expense. Neale Daniher did the gag with me saying that we’re going to get extra people to push you down and everyone’s hoping you’re not going to get up out of the water. That’s where it was all at – the fun and stupidity. “However, it was clearly banter, but on White Ribbon weekend, we have to be ever-vigilant in stamping out anything that could be misconstrued one iota of supporting the abhorrent act of domestic violence. “The only thing I’ll say there is that it was all done in the spirit of the fun of the day and who would be next going down the slide. Totally unacceptable.” McGuire was on last Monday’s radio segment with North Melbourne president James Brayshaw, journalist Damian Barrett and former players-turned-pundits, Danny Frawley and Wayne Carey. At the time, only Barrett expressed a reticence to join in the “banter”. Brayshaw and Frawley were also contacted by the AFL on Sunday. Frawley issued a brief apology on the Fox Sports show, Bounce, later in the day and another on Monday morning, when he said he had left a “very apologetic message” with Wilson. “A lot of people have been affected by it and none more than Caroline Wilson,” he said. “I do take it back. It was in jest but when you read it in isolation it doesn’t look good.” Brayshaw is expected to address the furore in his radio show on Monday afternoon. The AFL on Sunday condemned the episode, saying it “had expressed the strong view to both club presidents and All Australian selector Danny Frawley ... that although seeking to be light-hearted, the language and tenor of the wording could be seen to be supporting violent attitudes or actions against women, and was therefore clearly not appropriate.” Wilson is the first woman to win the AFL’s gold media award and she has won several awards during her career, including the AFL Players Association’s football writer of the year and the AFL Media Association’s most outstanding football writer and most outstanding feature writer. “In my mind, anyway we’re talking about a colleague of ours who gives as good as she gets,” McGuire said. “She’s skewered all of us and that’s the tone I was talking in – that it’d be good to see her going down the slide because she’s given it to all of us over the journey. “I don’t even consider Caroline Wilson other than being a person and being a leading light in football. It was nothing personal. In the context of what we’re fighting for, and that is that violence against women is abhorrent and we have to take the extra steps.”
